article.title: Zero delay anti-bunching as an entanglement signature for plasmonically coupled driven qubits

choices: The experimental setup for measuring plasmonically mediated entanglement.
A schematic diagram of two quantum dots coupled to a shared plasmonic reservoir.
The energy levels of two quantum dots driven by external fields.
The time evolution of a single quantum dot coupled to a plasmon.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1(b), what do the solid and dashed lines represent?
choices: Solid lines: Experimental results; Dashed lines: Theoretical predictions.
Solid lines: Full numerical solution; Dashed lines: Effective analytical solution.
Solid lines: Dynamics with dissipation; Dashed lines: Dynamics without dissipation.
Solid lines: Population of ground state; Dashed lines: Population of excited state.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main insight provided by Figure 2?
choices: Anti-symmetric detunings always lead to maximal entanglement.
Steady state concurrence can be maximized by tuning qubit detunings and driving fields.
Qubit coupling strength does not significantly impact the steady state entanglement.
Plasmon detuning and driving have a negligible effect on the concurrence.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the dark bands in the heat maps of Figure 2?
choices: They represent regions of high qubit dephasing rates.
They indicate parameter regimes where the system exhibits strong anti-bunching.
They highlight areas where the effective two-qubit Rabi frequency is minimized.
They show the parameter space where the plasmon relaxation dominates the dynamics.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between g(2)(0) and concurrence (C) illustrated in Figure 3?
choices: As concurrence increases, g(2)(0) also increases, indicating stronger photon bunching.
A g(2)(0) value of 0.5 always corresponds to a maximally entangled state.
Minimum g(2)(0) values coincide with maximum concurrence, signifying anti-bunching and entanglement.
Figure 3 demonstrates that g(2)(0) is independent of the driving amplitude.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3(b) reveal about the impact of dephasing noise on entanglement and anti-bunching?
choices: Dephasing noise has a negligible effect on both concurrence and g(2)(0).
Increasing dephasing noise strengthens the anti-bunching signature.
High dephasing rates lead to an increase in the population of the doubly excited state.
Dephasing noise reduces both the concurrence and the depth of the anti-bunching dip.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key message conveyed by the color map in Figure 5?
choices: It depicts the steady state concurrence as a function of qubit detunings and driving amplitudes.
It shows the dependence of the effective two-qubit Rabi frequency on system parameters.
It illustrates the variation in the anti-bunching signal timescale with qubit detunings and driving fields.
It represents the influence of dephasing noise on the entanglement generation process.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of achieving anti-bunching timescales in the ~10 ps range?
choices: It allows for the observation of anti-bunching using readily available experimental techniques.
It confirms that the anti-bunching originates from the plasmon reservoir and not the individual qubits.
It ensures that the anti-bunching signal is robust against environmental noise and decoherence.
It enables the use of state-of-the-art time-tagging electronics for accurate measurement of g(2)(τ).

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the second-order temporal correlation function, g(2)(τ), quantify?
choices: The probability of finding the system in an entangled state.
The degree of temporal correlation between photon emission events.
The strength of the coupling between the qubits and the plasmonic reservoir.
The rate of information leakage due to environmental interactions.
